data.title: Mouse wheel scrolling is 3x faster when hovering scrollbar
data.body:
Godot 2.1.4
Windows 10 64 bits

I just noticed that in the script editor, if you use the mouse wheel over the text, it scrolls normally, but if you hover the vertical scrollbar it scrolls 3 times faster. Not sure if that's intented.

It also happens in the scene tree, probably in more places.

data.title: str2var() breaks if the string contains a "(" or a ")" - it fails to convert the string to a Vector2
data.body:
trying to convert a vector2 string that was stored in a json file with
`str2var("(93, 87)")`
The "(" and ")"  in the string crash the application

I get this error:
`calling built-in function 'str2var': Parse error at line 120945184: Expected value, got '('. `

this is a follow up to:
https://github.com/godotengine/godot/issues/11419

data.title: Allow equality checks between null and arbitrary types
data.body:
Uninitialzed values in GDScript are of type NIL so not allowing null
comparisons did end up breaking some code.

This commit reenables NULL equality checks for all types. We're going to
have to figure out how to make this fast for the compiler later.

Fixes #11430.

The original complaint about this was something like this: (but to do with input) https://github.com/godotengine/godot-demo-projects/pull/66

```gdscript
func _ready():
  var x 
  while true:
    if x < 10:
      x = 10
      break
```
Allowing you to treat an uninitialized value as something of any type for this case, of course initializing the value fixes that.

This makes the following valid GDScript:
```gdscript
func _ready():
        var x

        if x == null: # x is null or unitialized
                x = 10

        if x != null:
                print("not null now")

        print(x)
```

Just to clarify: This is valid GDScript2, but after the stricter type checking was no longer valid GDScript3. The question is do we want the above code to be valid GDScript or not.

If this PR is not merged the above can be achieved as follows:

```gdscript
func _ready():
    var x
    if not x: # X 0 or unitialized
      x = 10

   if x:
      print("not null or 0")

   print(x)
```
or just initialize (and thereby type) the variable. If you really must know whether something is initialized vs 0 a typeof() can still work, but even then does that mean 'initialized' or not?

There's a case to be made here to just make unitialized variables a syntax error too I suppose. GDScript doesn't really need 

Or just not let people declare variables without typing them, that'd do it too. I'm kind of leaning in that direction myself but it would be a larger change, semantics wise.

data.title: Poor macOS magic mouse touch scrolling support
data.body:
**Operating system or device, Godot version, GPU Model and driver (if graphics related):**
macOS Sierra 10.12.5 
Godot 2.1.3-stable
any magic mouse with a touch surface

**Issue description:**
The apple magic mouse's touch/scroll event handling is poorly handled in the godot editor:

1. A magic mouse's touch scroll zooms excessively in the visual editor.  Any minor scroll gestures cause the editor to zoom by several thousand percent.  This makes using the mouse a hinderance on macOS as even accidentally smudging your finger can unexpectedly throw the editor (and you) way off.  

2. The script editor is similarly too sensitive, and scrolls too readily (though it's manageable, possibly as a side effect of 3 below).  

3. Script editor fling gestures behave strangely, with the editor scrolling at a consistent rate before abruptly stopping.   I would expect the fling scrolling velocity to start fast and gradually tail off.  See scrolling in other macOS apps for example expected behaviour.

Other apps, such as Unity, are able to support the mouse's touch events seamlessly (in fact I'd look to Unity for an example of expected zoom behaviour).

**Steps to reproduce:**
Open godot's 2D editor.  Interact with the surface of the mouse.  The editor will zoom almost uncontrollably.

Open godot's script editor.  Attempt to scroll a line or two at a time.  Use a fling gesture to scroll down a large file.

**Link to minimal example project:**
n/a

data.title: Set Android minSdkVersion to 18
data.body:
It's the minimum version where GLES 3 API is available. It is already
the version Godot binary is compiled with for Android, but the config
files were not updated in time.

data.title: Return player ID after connecting to Game Center
Comparing with null causes type error
data.body:
**Operating system or device, Godot version, GPU Model and driver (if graphics related):**
Godot 3.0 commit cd2ffdc6725aa6f7a9a4af6fd5abcc4cafae61b4

**Issue description:**
Comparing something with `null` causes type error.
For example:
```
var s = "string"
if s != null:
	print("not null")
```
Results in
`Invalid operands 'String' and 'Nil' in operator '!='`

I think, 85641c545bedbdb703ad923306786afe5c312110 caused this.

Edit: This is only for non-object types. Like, strings, arrays, dictionaries and numbers.

data.title: Shader paramater types don't get updated in the inspector tab once set
data.body:
**Operating system or device, Godot version, GPU Model and driver (if graphics related):**
Master https://github.com/godotengine/godot/commit/cd2ffdc6725aa6f7a9a4af6fd5abcc4cafae61b4

**Issue description:**
<!-- What happened, and what was expected. -->
When updating the shader uniforms type the inspector won't update the type if there was already a value in the param.

[Video](https://streamable.com/agoya)

**Steps to reproduce:**
1. Create a shader.
2. Add an uniform.
3. Go to the inspector and give a value to that uniform.
4. Change the uniform type and save the shader.
5. The inspector will still hold the old type.

---

EDIT:
I feel this problem is the same or pretty much related to this issue so I'm appending it to this.

**Issue description:**
<!-- What happened, and what was expected. -->
When removing an uniform from the shader the inspector tab will get updated BUT if you add the uniform back the inspector tab will show the old value of that uniform

[Video](https://streamable.com/hk1kh)

**Steps to reproduce:**
1. Create a shader.
2. Add an uniform.
3. Go to the inspector and give a value to that uniform.
4. Remove the uniform.
5. The inspector will get updated removing the param from the list.
6. Add the uniform again.
6. The inspector will show the old value of the "new" uniform.

data.title: [WIP] Filesystem dock folder handling
data.body:
Issues  #11336 and #9854 raise a point about not being able to do some common tasks from within the file system dock. 

Folders now support the following on right click:
- Move
- Rename _(The "Move or Rename" option was split, as a save as dialog doesn't make sense for folders)_
- Delete
- Copy path _(For consistency with files right click)_
- Open in explorer _(For consistency with files right click)_
- New folder

Fixes the following issues:
- Dragging a folder in the folder tree could cause broken dependencies _(possibly cause of #5684)_
- If a move or rename fails, dependencies could be updated anyway
- Files which were going to be deleted could also be listed as having broken dependencies in the dependency removal dialog.

This PR has also had to rework the rename & move code to fix bugs with/better support folders, as a result I have also spent some time tidying up and removing duplicated code in these methods. I also have reworked the DependencyRemoveDialog to properly support removing folders.

data.title: Fix base _chmod return value
AnimationPlayer can't interpolate vec4 shader parameters
data.body:
**Operating system or device, Godot version, GPU Model and driver (if graphics related):**
Master 67aa409f596515894fa855492a31976a3044381c

**Issue description:**
<!-- What happened, and what was expected. -->
AnimationPlayer can't interpolate between two vec4 values because they are a `Variant` `PLANE` type and this type doesn't have an interpolate function here:

https://github.com/godotengine/godot/blob/master/core/variant_op.cpp#L3103-L3105

**Steps to reproduce:**
See attached example.


**Link to minimal example project:**
<!-- Optional but very welcome. You can drag and drop a zip archive to upload it. -->
[animplayer_shader_vec4.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/1315965/animplayer_shader_vec4.zip)

data.title: Implements set_margins_preset(...)
data.body:
Allows to set margins using a Layout preset like for anchors.
Replaces set_area_as_parent_rect in most cases.

It should allow for a new menu to automatcally move control nodes relatively to its parent. (now it only exists for anchors)

data.title: Crash on startup if there is no audio device connected
data.body:
**Operating system or device, Godot version, GPU Model and driver (if graphics related):**
Windows 7 64 bits

**Issue description:**

If there is no audio device connected, Godot will crash on startup with the following error:

```
ERROR: init_device: Condition ' hr != ((HRESULT)0x00000000) ' is true. returned: ERR_CANT_OPEN
   At: drivers\wasapi\audio_driver_wasapi.cpp:54
ERROR: init: Condition ' err != OK ' is true. returned: err
   At: drivers\wasapi\audio_driver_wasapi.cpp:155
ERROR: initialize: Initializing audio failed.
   At: platform\windows\os_windows.cpp:1088
Segmentation fault
```

**Steps to reproduce:**

- Remove all your playback devices until there is none activated.
- Run Godot.
- Observe crash.
- Ask yourself how can you live without some damn headphones.

data.title: Better script code font size rescaling on retina displays
data.body:
A more complete version of #11421 (i.e. bug fix plus enhancements):

- larger steps for font size changes on retina displays
- scaling is now guaranteed to always have an effect (the old code could get you in a lock up if the font went too small or too big)

data.title: Fixes code font size jump on retina displays after font resizing
data.body: If you're on a retina display and you zoom in or out the script code font size using "command and mouse wheel", you're up for a surprise, because as soon as you release command, the font size jumps to the double size of what you intended, leaving you in a bad place (unable to scale it down as it's now above 96 points). This fixes this font size jumping.

data.title: Less strict equality checks
data.body:
What happens without this PR - in most cases an error is generated - `Invalid operands 'int' and 'String' in operator '=='`. This PR allows equality checks between any types of variants without errors:
```gdscript
var vars = [null, 0, 1, 1.1, "1", [], {},Vector2(), Vector3(), Node.new(), Reference.new(), Transform(), Transform2D(), NodePath("/")]
for i in range(vars.size()):
	for j in range(vars.size()):
		if i == j:
			assert(vars[i] == vars[j])
			assert(vars[j] == vars[i])
		else:
			assert(vars[i] != vars[j])
			assert(vars[j] != vars[i])
```
Some discussion was started here #11388. It also fixes #11411.

This PR is more like discussion over something should be merged right now. I'm not c++ pro and did it to provide my point of view first of all. I believe equality checks should not generate any errors, this is completely unexcepted behaviour, especially for such dynamicaly typed language as GDScript. I won't receive any errors just for asking is Monkey the same thing as Banana. I want false result in this case. Python (for example) is OK with equality checks of different types. In most cases this is matter of aesthetics, but if we think about how external data can be changed over time equality checks behaviour becomes incredibly important.

data.title: string.split and string.split_floats writes a 0 on the first entry in the resulting array, instead of the correct value
data.body:
Consider the following code:
```
func _ready():
	var myVec2String = "(93, 87)"
	var strArr = str(myVec2String).split_floats(',')
	print("vector2 string:",myVec2String," and after split, -->",strArr, " as you can see the first is a zero, instead of 93")
```

This is the resulting print out:
`vector2 string:(93, 87) and after split, -->[0, 87] as you can see the first is a zero, instead of 93`

I am running the stable version of Godot btw

This is particularly bad when you need to read a vector2 from a json file

data.title: Fix crash handler not including stdlib.h
data.body: Fixes #11414.

data.title: Weird lanes of pixels in tilemaps
data.body:
**Operating system or device, Godot version, GPU Model and driver (if graphics related):**
Linux + Windows. Tested in both Nvidia 970M, Intel 520 and R480. Tested alpha1 and a nightly version (build at 15:30 2017/09/27
For some weird reason only renders right on the radeon on linux.
I have tried to do a clean instalation of godot (cleaning all config files)

**Issue description:**
Right: imported png with region activated (16x16 pixels)
Left: 16x16 tilemap with the image of the left imported as tileset
![imagen](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/11560400/30596207-c10eb7b2-9d53-11e7-8022-154a450c2272.png)

If in the image of the right I check "filter clip" they both looks the same.
I have noticed issue https://github.com/godotengine/godot/issues/9925 but it seems not resolved for me on a nightly build (details of my build at top)

**Steps to reproduce:**
1.- Import a png and cut it.
2.-Create a tileset with these image.
3.- Use these image in a tilemap



**Link to minimal example project:**
<!-- Optional but very welcome. You can drag and drop a zip archive to upload it. -->
[test.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/1314497/test.zip)

data.title: Viewports with Transparent Bg=false and Usage=2D dither alpha
data.body:
**Operating system or device, Godot version, GPU Model and driver (if graphics related):**
Linux (Arch), 3.0 62cb43bb8dec8f5078012b58ff06a2077078565f, Intel integrated

**Issue description:**
<!-- What happened, and what was expected. -->
When Transparent Bg is not checked, viewports with Usage=2D will dither alpha, even on non-transparent backgrounds:
![https://cdn.pbrd.co/images/GL5WXZP.png](https://cdn.pbrd.co/images/GL5WXZP.png)
Left is without Transparent Bg, Right is with Transparent Bg.

Note: Thinking about it, it might be somewhat intended, but the fact that it happens only with usage = 2D is strange..

**Steps to reproduce:**
1. Add a ViewportContainer with a Viewport as an only child.
2. Resize the viewport container so that it takes the whole screen (adjust anchor and margins).
3. Set the viewport to usage = 2D
4. Add some mostly-opaque sprite in the viewport.
5. Add something semi-transparent on top of the sprite.
6. Run the project.

**Link to minimal example project:**
Example using Polygon2D with transparent color: [transparent-bg-viewport.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/1314491/transparent-bg-viewport.zip)

data.title: question about websockets ?
data.body:
> On 22 June 2016, Godot received a $20,000 Mozilla Open Source Support (MOSS) Mission Partners award to be used to add Web Sockets, WebAssembly and WebGL 2.0 support.[16]

just curious if web socket support is planned yet? i know a lot of work has been don with 3.0, but i'm currently wanting to use the [uws nodejs](https://github.com/uNetworking/bindings/tree/master/nodejs) library (**fastest** websocket lib for nodejs), and really want to use Godot with it!!

i have a large game i made in html 5 that uses that library but don't really want to mess with TCP and doing my own message protocol solution.  but, game is around 10,000 lines of code and already converting it over to Godot now with the beautiful `gdscript` language. really easy coming from javascript tbh :) cannot wait

god bless, ty for the engine!!  sorry for english

data.title: NodePath cant be compared with null
data.body:
**Operating system or device, Godot version, GPU Model and driver (if graphics related):**
Linux, 3d06957f12ba5c04702f3db980af9c07142e7886

**Issue description:**
It's impossible to compare NodePath with null. It will give `Invalids operands 'NodePath' and 'Nil' in operator '=='.` error

**Steps to reproduce:**
1. Create new scene.
2. Add `Node` type to the scene root
3. Attach this script to the `Node`:
```
extends Node
var someNodePath = NodePath();
func _ready():
	if(someNodePath == null):  #Invalids operands 'NodePath' and 'Nil' (...)
		pass
	else:
		print("it's ok");

```
4. Run the scene

**Update 1:** From my bisection it seems that 137f8a5 is the first bad commit
